awd_titl_txt: Parity Violating Electron Scattering and Nucleon Structure Studies at Jefferson Lab
awd_abstract_narration:
It is now a well-established fact that nucleons, protons and neutrons, are made up of more elementary particles called quarks.  This grant will support present and future experiments at Jefferson Lab to investigate the quark structure of protons and neutrons. In particular, these experiments will explore how electrons scatter from the proton and from other electrons in a way which will test the fundamental theoretical model of physics, called the Standard Model. These experiments will help to advance the field of nuclear and particle physics, as well as provide a world class education to the graduate and undergraduate students working on those projects.

In the electron scattering experiments at Jefferson Laboratory in which the Louisiana Tech group is involved, many new physical observables will be measured.  The physics available from these measurments include measurements of inherent properties of the weak interaction, allowing us to test predictions of the Standard Model of Particles and Interactions, and in particular the weak interaction parameter. Additional measurements will further probe the internal structure of protons and neutrons, providing tests of predictions from existing theoretical models.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF award number 1509547 granted to researchers at Louisiana Tech University
during the time period 6/15/2015 through 5/31/2020 was used to support research
efforts at Jefferson Laboratory in Newport News, VA. The primary focus of these
efforts were to use an experimental technique known as Parity Violating Electron
Scattering. In this technique a polarized electron beam is scattered from various
nuclear targets that allow a probe of Weak Interaction fundamental quantities, where
the Weak Interaction is one of the four fundamental forces in nature, and constitutes
an important part of the Standard Model of Particles and Interactions, a very successful
model that decribes the nature of particles and their interactions.

Two major projects in which the Louisiana Tech researchers were involved at Jefferson
Lab were the Qweak project and the MOLLER project. In the Qweak project, use is made
of Parity Violating Electron Scattering to make the first ever measurement of the proton's
weak charge. The proton's weak charge determines how strongly the Weak Interaction "pulls"
on the proton, much as the proton's electric charge determines how strongly the electromagnetic
interaction "pulls" on the proton. The Qweak project was successfully carried out at Jefferson
Lab, and when the data were completely analyzed, a high precision measurement of the proton's
weak charge was obtained. This result was considered important enough to be selected for
publication in the highly presigeous journal Nature. The result was also presented to scientists
around the world at several international venues, including one such presentation by a
Louisiana Tech researcher in Havana, Cuba.

As part of the Qeak project, several other physics measurements were made primarily to
constrain various physics background contributions to the main Qweak measurement. It was
soon realized, however, that many of these physics measurements had never been made, and
were worthy of Ph.D. dissertation projects for several graduate students at the institutions
collaborating on the Qweak project, as well as worthy of publications in peer reviewed journals.
One such additional physics measurement of particular interest to the Louisiana Tech researchers
was the measurement of the Parity Violating asymmetry in the N to Delta transition, where the
Delta is the name of the first excited state of the proton. This asymmetry characterizes how
the spins in the proton redistrubute during its energy change to this excited state. The
analysis of the data taken on this excited state during the Qweak project resulted in two
Ph.D. degrees awarded to graduate students at Louisiana Tech during the NSF award time period.
Publications on this physics topic are expected in the near future.

The other major project at Jefferson Lab in which the Louisiana Tech researchers and their
students continue to be involved is the MOLLER project. The MOLLER experiment is expected
to be performed within the next few years. This experiment also uses Parity Violating Electron
Scattering, but the polarized incident electrons scatter instead of other target electrons,
and therefore provide a measurement of the electron's weak charge, giving complementary information
about the Weak Interaction that that provided by the proton weak charge measurement. Since this
experiment was in the design stage during the NSF award time period, much of the effort
put forth by the Lousiana Tech researchers and their students was concentrated on design and
simulation of the equipment to be used during the MOLLER experiment data taking phase. As this
is a large and complicated experimental apparatus, many design and simulation projects were
required, resulting in 6 Master of Science degrees were awarded to Louisiana Tech graduate
students during this time period.

I total, 2 Ph.D. degrees and 6 M.S. degrees were awarded to Louisiana Tech graduate students
as a result of the Louisiana Tech researchers efforts on these two Jefferson Lab projects,
as well as 3 Senior Physics project for B.S. Physics students at Louisiana Tech. In addition,
7 refereed journal publications have resulted from these efforts in the NSF award time period,
with several more from the Qweak project expected in the very near future, and several additional
publications and Ph.D. degrees expected in the not too distant future for efforts on the MOLLER
project.
